channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: With Attacks on Ukraine, Putin Gives Hard-Liners What They Wanted
item.description: A sharp shift toward deadly strikes signaled that domestic pressure over Russia’s flailing war effort had escalated to the point where Vladimir Putin felt a decisive show of force was necessary.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency services workers on Monday at the site of an overnight missile strike in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine.

item.title: Lukashenko Says Russian Troops Will Return to Belarus in Large Numbers
item.description: Statements by President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, an eccentric and highly erratic dictator, are rarely an accurate guide to current or future events.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Markus Schreiber/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Alexander Lukashenko at the Independence Palace in Minsk, Belarus, in May.

item.title: Mastriano’s Attacks on Jewish School Set Off Outcry Over Antisemitic Signaling
item.description: The G.O.P. candidate for governor, who promotes Christian power and disdains separation of church and state, is alarming Jewish voters in his contest with the Democratic candidate, Josh Shapiro, who is Jewish.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Mastriano has rattled a diverse swath of Pennsylvania’s Jewish community, alarming liberal Jews with his far-right associations and remarks.

item.title: British Official Stresses Threat From China Even Amid Russian Aggression
item.description: The head of Britain’s GCHQ spy agency warned that the West should not lose sight of the technological challenge from China as it deals with the immediate problem of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Jade Gao/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The director of Britain’s cyber and electronic intelligence agency said he was skeptical about how far China would go to support Russia’s aggression.

item.title: Stewart Rhodes is Not the Only Oath Keeper on Trial
item.description: The stories of the four other members of the far-right militia also facing charges of seditious conspiracy help flesh out the group’s role around the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jared Ramsdell/Journal Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Justice Department set out its case against Stewart Rhodes, above, and four other members of the far-right Oath Keepers militia.

item.title: That Reusable Trader Joe’s Bag? It’s Rescuing an Indian Industry.
item.description: India’s deep-rooted jute industry has struggled for decades, undercut by cheaper synthetics. Now its bags are a sought-after biodegradable alternative.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hukumchand Jute Mill in the Indian state of West Bengal, where the country’s jute industry is concentrated.

item.title: Older People Hit By Hurricane Ian Face an Uncertain Future
item.description: Retirees displaced by Hurricane Ian confront a wrenching situation: At their age, remaking the lives they loved so much in Florida may not be possible.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: After seeing their home in Fort Myers, Fla., ravaged by Hurricane Ian, Del and Jane Compton are planning to move back to Louisville, Ky.

item.title: Los Angeles Labor Federation Chief Resigns in Furor Over Leaked Conversation
item.description: Ron Herrera was part of a secretly recorded conversation in which the Los Angeles City Council president, Nury Martinez, mocked Indigenous immigrants and the Black child of a fellow council member.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Photo by PATRICK T. FALLON/AFP via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ron Herrera, President of the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor, resigned on Monday night.

item.title: Inside Mark Zuckerberg’s Metaverse Struggles
item.description: Meta’s push to develop virtual and augmented reality technology has had a bumpy year.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Sheera Frenkel and Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Amy Osborne/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, introducing the Oculus Quest virtual-reality headset in 2019.

item.title: As Warehouses Multiply, Some California Cities Say: Enough
item.description: Several municipalities in California’s Inland Empire have halted new projects to study their impact on pollution and congestion, but labor and business groups have warned that moratoriums could cost the region tax revenue and jobs.
item.dc:creator: Kurtis Lee and Alex Welsh
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A warehouse abuts a residential street in Colton, Calif.

item.title: Jennifer Siebel Newsom, Wife of Gov. Gavin Newsom, To Testify in Harvey Weinstein’s L.A. Trial
item.description: Jennifer Siebel Newsom, a documentary filmmaker and former actor, has accused the once-powerful film mogul, Harvey Weinstein, of sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Etienne Laurent
item.media:description: Harvey Weinstein during a court appearance in Los Angeles last week.

item.title: Douglas Kirkland, Who Took Portraits of Movie Stars, Dies at 88
item.description: His many memorable shots included one of his earliest assignments and probably his most famous: Marilyn Monroe in bed, wrapped in a silk sheet.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: The Midterms Aren’t the Only Things That Are Looming
item.description: Borders all over the world are in dispute, and they are not all geographical.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Ed Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An unfinished section of the border wall near Roma, Texas.

item.title: My Elders in Pakistan Predicted Calamity. Now It’s Here.
item.description: This is what happens when the floodwaters come.
item.dc:creator: Ibrahim Buriro
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: Xi Jinping Is a Captive of the Communist Party Too
item.description: It may appear that Xi Jinping has taken over the party, but it’s the other way around.
item.dc:creator: Kerry Brown
item.media:credit: Noel Celis/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images

item.title: The Exploitative Anti-Blackness of Kanye West
item.description: By wearing a “White Lives Matter” shirt, Kanye West gave white supremacists a boost.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Scott Dudelson/FilmMagic, via Getty Images

item.title: Russia’s New Onslaught Against Ukraine
item.description: Readers respond to the latest Russian attacks in Ukraine. Also: The wonders of math; pandemic spending; Republicans and crime.
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Joe Biden Knows How to Use Donald Trump
item.description: A lot of politicians would have vied with Trump to make the election about them.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: How I Fell In Love With Loretta Lynn
item.description: Loretta Lynn was complicated. Love is, too.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images

item.title: Why Must Puerto Ricans Always Be Resilient?
item.description: We are tired of celebrating our ability to endure, of being creative in the face of adversity.
item.dc:creator: Yarimar Bonilla
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left, Alejandro Granadillo/Associated Press; Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times; Alejandro Granadillo/Associated Press; Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, Salinas Beach in Puerto Rico; a power outage in Yauco; a house in Salinas; Nereida Batista at her home in Toa Baja.

item.title: Experiencing the majestic monsoon
item.description: Scientists warn that global warming is altering South Asia’s epic rainy season in dangerous ways. Our reporter went to investigate.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indians gathered under rainy skies in Mumbai in September to celebrate Ganesh Visarjan, part of a 10-day Hindu festival commemorating the birth of the god Ganesha.

item.title: The Yates Report Isn’t the End. It’s Just the Start.
item.description: Women’s soccer players tried to raise the alarm about abuse for years. When they say there’s more, people should listen.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.category: United States Women's National Soccer Team
item.media:credit: Paul Childs/Action Images Via Reuters
item.media:description: “Even when you know it,” Megan Rapinoe said of a report about abuse in women’s soccer, “it’s just horrifying over and over to read.”

item.title: The Sudden Rise of Zach Bryan
item.description: The breakout country-folk singer and songwriter has found an audience for his old-fashioned artistry largely on a newer platform: streaming.
item.media:credit: Kristin Braga Wright for The New York Times

item.title: Did the Pandemic Deepen Relationships in Your Life? We Want To Hear About It.
item.description: Tell us about relationships that started during the pandemic and ones that have evolved or been shaped by the last few years.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Naomieh Jovin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The pandemic has affected all kinds of relationships, from family bonds and friendships to romantic connections.

item.title: Nikki Finke, Caustic Hollywood Chronicler, Is Dead at 68
item.description: At newspapers and then at Deadline, the website she founded, she served up the opposite of fluff entertainment journalism.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: U.K. Government Plans an Update to Its Tax and Spending Agenda
item.description: After an earlier announcement sent markets into a tailspin, the prime minister and the chancellor are under pressure to restore fiscal credibility.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Paul Ellis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, Kwasi Kwarteng. The government plans to show nearly a month earlier than it had how it intends to bring down debt levels.

item.title: After Giving Up on Cancer Vaccines, Doctors Start to Find Hope
item.description: Encouraging data from preliminary studies are making some doctors feel optimistic about developing immunizations against pancreatic, colon and breast cancers.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Matt Roth for The New York Times

item.title: Biden’s Folksiness Can Veer Into Folklore, or Falsehoods
item.description: President Biden has been unable to break himself of the habit of embellishing narratives to weave a political identity.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden has embraced storytelling as a way of connecting with his audience, but his folksiness can veer into a personal folklore.

item.title: What Are Your ‘Non-Negotiables’? Readers Share Wellness Rituals
item.description: Reading Nancy Drew. Watching the birds every day. Counting yellow doors. Thousands of Times readers shared their wellness “non-negotiables.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Andrea Chronopoulos
item.media:credit: Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: Fall Allergies: What to Know About Causes, Symptoms and Care
item.description: Climate change is making this allergy season longer and more intense. Here’s how to cope.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Hangover Anxiety: How a Night of Drinking Can Tank Your Mood
item.description: Consuming alcohol can mess with your emotions the next day by causing stress hormones to spike and sleep to be disrupted overnight.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Pablo Delcan

item.title: What is Microdosing, and Does it Work?
item.description: Scientists are split over whether the benefits some microdosers experience are a placebo effect or something more.
item.dc:creator: Dana G Smith
item.media:credit: River Cousin

item.title: How to Spot ‘Medical Gaslighting’ and What to Do About It.
item.description: Experts share tips on advocating for yourself in a health care setting.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Lucy Jones

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
